desc: The MSI1 protein plays a role in translationalregulation of cell fate, and is associated with grade and proliferative activity in gliomas and melanomas.

MSI1 encodes the RNA-binding protein Musashi1, whichbinds to consensus RNA sequence GU3-5(G or AG) on specific mRNAs, and controls their expression by translational repression. In mammals, the Musashi family of RNA-binding proteins is known to be important for cell fate determination, neural development, and maintenance of stem-cell state, differentiation, and tumorigenesis. Musashi-1 protein is selectively expressed in neural progenitor cells, including neural stem cells (PMID: 9790759). Musashi-1protein, in co-operation with Musashi-2, activates Notch signaling through translational repression of mNumb mRNA, an intracellular Notch signal repressor, and maintains the self-renewingability of neural stem cells (NSCs) (PMID: 15925591). Musashi-1-mediated activation of the Wnt pathway also serves to sustain mammary gland stem cell pools (PMID: 18362162). In addition, Musashi-1 is aselective marker for intestinal stem or early lineage cells (PMID: 12924647, 15925591). Elevated Musashi-1 expression is present in gliomas and glioblastomas, and correlates with the malignancy and proliferativeactivity of the tumor (PMID: 11284014, 11896183).
articles/0/title: Expression of the neural RNA-binding protein Musashi1 in human gliomas.
articles/1/title: Musashi1 modulates mammary progenitor cell expansion through proliferin-mediated activation of the Wnt and Notch pathways.
articles/2/title: Expression of Musashi-1 in human normal colon crypt cells: a possible stem cell marker of human colon epithelium.
articles/3/title: Musashi: a translational regulator of cell fate.
articles/4/title: Function of RNA-binding protein Musashi-1 in stem cells.
articles/5/title: The human Musashi homolog 1 (MSI1) gene encoding the homologue of Musashi/Nrp-1, a neural RNA-binding protein putatively expressed in CNS stem cells and neural progenitor cells.
